channel.title: BUbreakingSectionTwo
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from BUbreakingSectionTwo, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Companies are trying to do too much with AI, says IT CEO: ‘Pick one or two domains and go end to end’
item.description: The key extracting ROI from gen AI projects is to choose your lane—and stay there.

item.title: Barry’s ‘cofounder’ unwinds at his own gym—but even he admits balance is elusive: ‘Many days I have to wake up and choose who I’m going to disappoint’
item.description: Barry’s chair went from joining the gym at 26 to running it—now, he still wears athletic wear to work, has the same lunch every day, and spends $2.70 ...

item.title: Trump Calls on Republicans to End Filibuster in Shutdown Fight
item.description: The president said it was time for G.O.P. leaders to get rid of the longstanding rule that means most Senate legislation needs 60 votes to pass.

item.title: Billie Eilish calls on billionaires to give away their wealth—with Mark Zuckerberg in the room: ‘If you’re a billionaire, why are you one?’
item.description: "No hate, but yeah, give your money away, shorties,” she said at the WSJ Magazine Innovator Awards.

item.title: In Louisiana, Threat of Lost SNAP Food Benefits Is Rattling the Vulnerable
item.description: The state has vowed to step in and provide food assistance for many who face a cut-off in federal SNAP aid. But there is still fear and anxiety about ...

item.title: Carney Plans to Meet With Xi to Try and Reset Relations
item.description: The leaders of Canada and China met for the first time in eight years to try to reset relations after years of acrimony.

item.title: Three Billionaires Walk Into a Fried Chicken Restaurant
item.description: Jensen Huang, the Nvidia chief executive, and the leaders of Samsung and Hyundai staged a regular-folks outing in Seoul before announcing a business d...

item.title: The government shutdown won’t be completely recouped—and it could cost the economy up to $14 billion, estimates say
item.description: The report says lost goods and services from furloughed workers’ downtime won’t be regained once the government reopens.

item.title: At the Supreme Court, Liberal Justices Are Split
item.description: We go inside their strained relationship.

item.title: Since ChatGPT launched, job openings have plunged 30% while the stock market has surged 70%—but one economist says the true culprit isn’t AI
item.description: It's been called "the scariest chart in the world."

item.title: Xi Delivers Veiled Warning to Nations Not to Take the U.S.’s Side
item.description: At an Asia-Pacific summit, the Chinese leader urged countries to “resist unilateral bullying,” an appeal that seemed at odds with his country’s recent...

item.title: Carney Plans to Meet With Xi to Try and Reset Relations
item.description: The leaders of Canada and China met for the first time in eight years to try to reset relations after years of acrimony.

item.title: How Saudi Arabia and Qatar Benefited From Rule Changes to Reach the World Cup
item.description: A soccer governing body that both countries have helped bankroll gave them extra rest and home-field advantage to set up World Cup qualification.

item.title: Exxon’s and Chevron’s Profits Fall as Oil Prices Stay Low
item.description: But the companies and other large oil producers are continuing to increase production because drilling still remains profitable.

item.title: Executions and Mass Casualties: Videos Show Horror Unfolding in Sudan
item.description: Evidence of atrocities emerging from the city of El Fasher stoked fears that the Sudanese region of Darfur is plunging, once again, into a cycle of ge...
